newsitem.title: GREECE: SHORT-END OF GREEK YIELD CURVE DOWN, 10-YR BOND UP.
newsitem.headline: SHORT-END OF GREEK YIELD CURVE DOWN, 10-YR BOND UP.

text.p: The short end of the Greek depo and forward curves tumbled on higher liquidity, and long tenors eased in calm trading, dealers said.

The 10-year bond recouped earlier losses with its gross redemption yield dipping to 9.18 percent from 9.21 percent but five- and seven-year bonds were trading lower, shrugging off lower interbank rates.

"Overnight drachmas are sharply down, trading around 9.90 percent and other short depos up to two months are also trading lower on forex inflows and the release of excess reserves," said a dealer at a foreign bank.
Longer depos have also eased a tenth of a point, he said.
"Implied drachmas rates from forex forwards have fallen a fifth of a point in short periods and a tenth of a point in longer tenors," the dealer said.

Lower interbank rates failed to spark a rally in bonds and FRNs with the exception of the 10-year bond where some local buying drove its yield down to 9.18 percent from 9.21 percent earlier, bond dealers said.

"Five-and seven-year bonds have not recovered their earlier losses but buying interest from local players has pushed the yield of the 10-year bond down to 9.18 percent," said a bond trader at a private bank.
The mark was quoted at 157.19/24 from Thursday's 157.480 fix, the dollar at 277.27/37 drachmas from 276.280 and the ecu at 309.36/46 from 309.55 drachmas.
"The mark firmed against the drachma picking up steam from a softer ecu/mark and dollar/mark," said a forex dealer at a foreign bank. "It is trading around 157.43/48."
The ecu/drachma cross was also trading close to the top of its intraday range of 309.60/65, dealers said.
